name: Peter Thiel
subtitle: Contrarian monopoly hunter
description: Peter frames every pitch around one uncomfortable question: what important truth does this company understand that the market still ignores? He favors startups that can move from a niche foothold to a durable monopoly through proprietary insight, technical edge, and strategic distribution advantages.

name: Marc Andreessen
subtitle: Platform and software expansion
description: Marc evaluates whether software can rewire an industry's economics and become the control layer for a much larger ecosystem. He is drawn to teams with product velocity, founder-market conviction, and a clear strategy to capture compounding platform effects over time.

name: Bill Gurley
subtitle: Marketplace and unit economics
description: Bill pushes founders to prove that growth is economically real, not merely subsidized acceleration. He studies contribution margins, take rates, and market structure to determine whether a business can scale efficiently once incentives normalize and competition intensifies.

name: Elad Gil
subtitle: Execution-first operator lens
description: Elad focuses on execution quality: can this team move quickly from product signal to repeatable go-to-market while scaling responsibly? He favors practical operators who can make high-leverage hiring, sequencing, and channel decisions under tight market timing windows.

name: Fred Wilson
subtitle: Community and network effects
description: Fred looks for products where user participation compounds value for everyone else, creating enduring network effects. He rewards founder clarity on community dynamics, governance, and ecosystem openness that can sustain trust while accelerating usage.

name: Arjun Sethi
subtitle: Data integrity watchdog
description: Arjun interrogates evidence quality before he accepts growth narratives, with special attention to cohort durability, conversion behavior, and signal hygiene. He prefers teams that can separate causation from noise and defend their metrics under adversarial scrutiny.

name: Reid Hoffman
subtitle: Strategic blitzscaling
description: Reid asks whether speed itself can become strategy in a winner-take-most market. He backs teams that understand when to prioritize rapid expansion, partnership leverage, and distribution lock-in, while still managing existential execution and organizational risks.

name: Sam Altman
subtitle: Category-defining ambition
description: Sam favors founders willing to pursue unusually ambitious technical missions with civilizational-scale upside. He evaluates whether the team can compound talent, capital, and learning fast enough to turn a high-risk frontier thesis into a dominant long-term platform.

name: Garry Tan
subtitle: Underdog conviction
description: Garry looks for overlooked founders with deep product intuition and unusually strong founder-market fit. He often values authentic builder momentum over polished storytelling, especially when the team is attacking ignored problems with obsessive customer empathy.

name: Vinod Khosla
subtitle: High-variance frontier bets
description: Vinod embraces portfolios where many experiments fail so a few transformative companies can redefine industries. He is comfortable with technical and market uncertainty when founders can articulate a plausible path to 10x outcomes and system-level impact.

name: Michael Moritz
subtitle: Narrative and founder endurance
description: Michael pays close attention to founder character, narrative discipline, and resilience through long execution cycles. He favors leaders who can maintain strategic coherence under volatility, communicate conviction effectively, and outlast competitors with operational stamina.

name: Kirsten Green
subtitle: Consumer behavior signaler
description: Kirsten studies cultural shifts and behavior loops to understand whether a product can become habitual and emotionally resonant. She values brands and experiences that evolve with consumer identity while preserving repeat usage and pricing power.

name: Steve Jurvetson
subtitle: Future-tech pattern matcher
description: Steve looks for discontinuous technologies that can ride steep S-curves from early skepticism to mainstream inevitability. He rewards teams with scientific depth, patient capital strategy, and credible paths to massive non-linear adoption.

name: Arthur Rock
subtitle: Character-first conviction
description: Arthur prioritizes founder integrity, judgment, and governance discipline as leading indicators of long-term outcomes. He believes durable companies are built by leaders who combine ethical credibility with calm decision-making during pivotal moments.

name: Don Valentine
subtitle: Market-size realism
description: Don starts from market demand, asking whether customer pain and budget are large enough to support a venture-scale business. He favors founders who combine clear commercialization pathways with disciplined focus on segments that can expand materially over time.

name: Paul Graham
subtitle: Founder craftsmanship
description: Paul looks for founders who build quickly, listen intensely, and keep improving the product through direct user contact. He emphasizes authentic problem obsession and craftsmanship in early execution, where small behavioral signals can predict outlier trajectories.

name: Clayton Christensen
subtitle: Disruption diagnostics
description: Clayton analyzes whether a startup is solving a job-to-be-done that incumbents structurally underserve. He seeks evidence that a low-end or new-market foothold can improve upmarket over time, eventually reshaping the competitive landscape.

name: Elon Musk
subtitle: First-principles pressure test
description: Elon rebuilds assumptions from physics, engineering constraints, and execution throughput rather than industry convention. He is attracted to teams pursuing radical performance gains, but he quickly discounts plans that ignore manufacturing, reliability, or timeline reality.

name: Thales Teixeira
subtitle: Customer-value-chain decoupling
description: Thales evaluates where customer journeys are fragmenting and where startups can unbundle value from incumbents. He favors business models that capture the most valuable interaction point and use superior experience to defend that new position.

name: Naval Ravikant
subtitle: Compounding leverage
description: Naval views startups through the lens of leverage and optionality, preferring businesses that scale through code, media, and networked systems rather than linear effort. He values founders with specific knowledge and patient strategic thinking that compounds over long horizons.
